cleaned_text: A shaman is a religious or mystical expert (male or female) who, in traditional [Indigenous](https://thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/aboriginal-people) societies, functions as a healer, prophet and custodian of cultural tradition.(See also [Religion and Spirituality of Indigenous Peoples in Canada](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/religion-of-aboriginal-people/).) Role of the Shaman Shamans are notable religious or spiritual figures present in many traditional [Indigenous](https://thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/aboriginal-people) faiths. They function as healers, prophets, diviners and custodians of religious lore. They are also often the coordinators of religious and cultural ceremonies, including the [Sun Dance](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/sun-dance/) (a world-renewal ceremony performed by [First Nations](https://thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/first-nations) on the Prairies) and the Winter Ceremony of the [Kwakwaka'wakw](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/kwakiutl/), [Nuu-chah-nulth](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/nootka-nuu-chah-nulth/) and other [Northwest Coast](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/northwest-coast/) communities. (See also [Northwest Coast Indigenous Peoples in Canada](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/aboriginal-people-northwest-coast/).) In some societies, all these functions are performed by the same person; in others, shamans are specialists. Healing practitioners may belong to various orders, such as the [Midewiwin](https://thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/midewiwin) or Great Medicine Society of the [Ojibwe](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/ojibwa/), while other groups have secret or closed societies, such as the Kwakwaka'wakw and [Siksika](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/blackfoot-siksika/). Members of such societies were not necessarily shamans but did practice religious ceremonies and rituals. Spiritual and Healing Powers Shamans were associated with powers generally thought to be beneficial to the community, but were believed in some cases to use their powers for sorcery. Shaman-prophets and diviners were concerned with predicting the outcome of the [hunt](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/hunting/), relocating lost objects, and determining the root causes of communal discontent and ill will. Siksika, [Cree](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/cree/), Ojibwe and other societies had diviners who made their prophecies (perhaps in trance states) in the dramatic [Shaking Tent](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/shaking-tent/) ceremony. Shamans in these societies were custodians of the sacred [medicine bundles](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/medicine-bundles) containing objects and materials endowed with great mystery and power. [Innu](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/inuit/) shamans divined game trails by burning a [caribou](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/caribou/) shoulder blade, then reading the cracks and fissures created by the fire. Shamans were often consulted at any time of sickness or communal misfortune. Natural causes were recognized for many diseases, especially physically curable ones; others were commonly believed to be the result of intrusion into the body of objects placed there by sorcerers. The shaman-healer's treatment of such diseases was dictated by his guardian spirit, but usually consisted of the shaman ritually sucking the disease agent out of the body, brushing it off with a bird's wing or drawing it out with dramatic gestures. Illness could also result from "spirit loss." The shaman-healer's action was then directed to recovering the patient's spirit (either the soul or guardian spirit power, or both) and reintroducing it to the body. Banning Shamanistic Rituals In 1880, the [Indian Act](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/indian-act/) was amended to prohibit the organization of, or participation in, certain traditional healing ceremonies, including [smudging](https://thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/smudging) - a sacred cleansing ceremony that involves the burning of various medicinal plants. Some societies continued to practice their traditions in secret, while others upheld the prohibition in fear of government prosecution. In the early 1950s, the government lifted bans on traditional healing ceremonies. As Indigenous peoples sought to reclaim traditions, Indigenous medicine began to re-emerge. By the 1980s, various shamanistic rituals and healing ceremonies gained popularity both within and outside Indigenous communities. Shamanism Today Many shaman-led healing ceremonies are still performed, including smudging, sharing circles and healing circles. Many modern shamans see themselves as facilitators for healing rather than healers themselves. Shamans offer healing techniques for those suffering from emotional, mental and physical pain. Often, such techniques include connecting with spirit guides, negative energy extraction, holistic remedies, engaging with nature and spiritual cleanses. Similar to their ancestors, modern shamans also perform rites of passage ceremonies, including births, marriages and deaths.
